question_metadata.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?

responses_by_article.article_title: A Pricing Framework for Software-as-a-Service
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: For clients: Faster consumption of innovation (new capabilities released simultaneously with upgrades)
For clients: Elimination of infrastructure management burden (outsourced to vendors)
For clients: Pay only for what is used (no upfront perpetual license fees)
For clients: Simplified licensing (only pay for use of subscribed software)
For vendors: Eliminate complexities and costs of managing multiple software versions
For vendors: Free up resources to focus on functionality enhancements and service innovations
For vendors: Achieve economies of scale through multi-tenant architecture
Market growth opportunity (26% compound annual growth rate expected)
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'The multi-tenant architecture of SaaS benefits both clients and vendors alike. For clients, the consumption of innovation is faster as new capabilities are released simultaneously with each service upgrade. For vendors, the complexities and costs associated with managing and maintaining multiple software versions can be eliminated, thereby freeing up resources to focus on functionality enhancements and service innovations' | Page 1: 'the global SaaS market is expected to reach 12.1 billion USD by 2014, reflecting a compound annual growth rate of 26%' | Page 3: 'From clients' perspective, such software licenses are greatly simplified for the fact that they only pay for their use of the subscribed software' | Page 2: 'clients are charged for only what they have utilized, usually on a periodic basis'

responses_by_article.article_title: Selection of the Proper Revenue and Pricing Model for SaaS
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Lower production costs (decreased traveling, installation, implementation, maintenance, after-sales support costs)
Flexible pricing options for customers
Easy and instant access to software from any location
Lower initial costs for customers compared to purchasing licenses
Faster implementation process
Ability to expand customer base to small and medium-sized customers
Protection against low switching costs through pricing strategies
Cost advantages and strategic benefits for customers
Reduced price competition and differentiation from traditional software providers
Ability to deliver updates immediately to all customers
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'Firm A prefers software renting on the grounds that it brings cost savings by decreasing production costs. These cost savings are related in particular to the traveling costs for installation, implementation, maintenance, and after-sales support within customers' premises' | Page 3: 'the rental model also made the software attractive for the customer as it was possible to have more flexible pricing models than in software licensing' | Page 2: 'opportunities related to the cost advantages of SaaS were the strongest driver for SaaS adoption' | Page 2: 'the adoption of SaaS is more related to strategic benefits than to economic benefits' | Page 5: 'Low initial costs in software renting enabled to expand the customer base from large-sized customers toward small and medium-sized customers'

responses_by_article.article_title: Transition to the Cloud: A Vendor Perspective
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Increasing market demands for cloud computing
Technological maturity of cloud solutions
Pressure from investors to increase company value through cloud transition
Cost efficiency and low entry costs for customers
Greater flexibility and scalability for customers
Competitive pressure from new cloud players (Salesforce, Amazon) and transitioning incumbents (Microsoft, SAP)
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 5, Section 5.2.1: 'The decision for the transition was on the one hand partially triggered by the macro environment with increasing market demands and technological maturity, and on the other hand pressured by the investor at the time as transition to cloud is likely to increase the value of the company.' | Page 1, Section 1: 'Over the recent years, we have seen new players, such as Salesforce.com and Amazon, introducing the new business models and obtaining first-mover advantages. In parallel, traditional software vendors, such as Microsoft and SAP, are also making the transition to cloud-based business models' | Page 1, Section 2: 'The advantages provided by this new way of consuming computing resources, such as low/minimal entry costs, pay-as-you-go mode, and great flexibility and scalability'

responses_by_article.article_title: Managing a Software Business
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Securing recurring revenue through service component
Low marginal distribution cost enabling additional sales to translate into pure profit
Ability to distribute on global scale and focus on profitable niche
Strong network effects increasing offering value with more users
Winner-takes-all positioning as hub can be remarkably rewarding
Platform/ecosystem strategy enabling business growth together with partners
Internet and cloud computing making it easy to include service component
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'Having a service component in your offering lets you secure recurring revenue.' | Page 1: 'The low marginal distribution cost (the cost of adding another user) means that additional sales can often directly translate into pure profit.' | Page 1: 'Software is also easy to distribute on a global scale. This can allow you to focus on a profitable niche.' | Page 2: 'Software, and especially a service built through it, exhibits strong network effects: your offering's value increases with the number of its users. Positioning yourself as a hub in a winner-takes-all field can be remarkably rewarding.' | Page 1: 'Thanks to the Internet and cloud computing, it's now easy to include a service component into any type of software.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Digital sustainable business models: Using digital technology to integrate ecological sustainability into the core of business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Ecological sustainability imperative - addressing global warming and climate change as urgent challenge
Economic and ecological complementarity - achieving both ecological and economic sustainability simultaneously
Combining two necessary transformations - digital and sustainable transformation together more efficient than separately
Creating competitive advantage through sustainability
Cost reduction through reduced resource usage
Legal compliance and increasing sustainability requirements
Addressing customer demand for sustainable products and services
Opportunity to be part of the solution rather than the problem of global warming
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'When confronted with the latest statistics on global warming (Pörtner et al., 2022), it becomes evident that incumbents can no longer compromise on ecological sustainability' | Page 2: 'These start-ups illustrate that ecological and economic sustainability are complementary and can be integral to a company's BM' | Page 2: 'as most companies are currently transitioning towards a digital BM (Vial, 2019), they can integrate ecological sustainability into their BMs as part of the same transformation, creating a new value proposition and reducing effort and costs compared to two separate transformations' | Page 15, Table 4: 'Cost-reduction through reduced resource usage' | 'Alternative solutions' | Page 2: 'the value proposition can go beyond cost efficiency and legal compliance'

responses_by_article.article_title: When does a freemium business model lead to high performance? — A qualitative comparative analysis based on fuzzy Sets
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Increase size of user base and benefit from network effects
Alleviate uncertainty associated with digital products for users
Increase user retention rate
Generate revenue from both subscription and advertising
Lower entry barriers for users (free trial)
Combat piracy by offering free legal alternative
Benefit from data-driven learning and user behavior analysis
Create multiple revenue streams (paid users and advertisers)
Achieve high performance and competitive advantage
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3, Section 2.1: 'It is often used by companies that are trying to increase the size of their user base and benefit from network effects' | 'users are more willing to try free products to alleviate the uncertainty associated with digital products. Freemium models increase a company's user retention rate and alleviate the uncertainty of digital products for users' | 'firms traded off between increasing the number of paying subscribers to gain subscription revenue and increasing the number of basic subscribers to gain advertising sponsorship revenue' | Page 3: 'scholars have examined its effectiveness in the context of piracy'

responses_by_article.article_title: Toward Building Specialized Information Systems as Software Platforms

Increased control over software
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 1: 'A software platform has the following benefits: 1) All-in-one solution: platforms provide an all-in-one solution for businesses' | Page 1: '2) Reduced costs: platforms are often less expensive than buying and integrating several specialized software applications' | Page 1: '3) Ease of use: platforms are designed to be user-friendly and easy to use' | Page 1: '4) Flexibility: platforms are flexible and can be customized to meet the specific needs of a business' | Page 1: '5) Scalability: platforms can be easily scaled to accommodate the growing needs of a business' | Page 1: '1) Speed to market: by being able to quickly implement new features, businesses can be much more agile and responsive to market demands' | Page 1: '2) Cost savings: developing new features in-house can be much cheaper than paying for a vendor to do it' | Page 1: '3) Increased control: by having more control over the software, businesses can ensure that it meets their specific needs'

responses_by_article.article_title: E-business evolution: an analysis of mobile applications' business models
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
responses_by_article.extracted_value: Adapting to digital transformation and mobile data technology revolution; surviving digital Darwinism by keeping pace with technological changes; finding the right business model to create and capture value in the new digital era; cutting spatial and timely barriers to value delivery for customers.
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'New and established entrepreneurs and strategists feel under pressure in adapting their firms to this change, among which, also finding the right business model, thus how to create and capture value (Amit and Zott 2001; Zott, Amit, and Massa 2011), seems another important challenge in order to survive the digital transformation and to crack open markets' | Page 2: 'today's firms are pushed, within the competitive phase of their business life cycle, to keep pace with the digital revolution driven by mobile data technologies –the so-called digital Darwinism by which firms who survive and continue competing are the ones that have been able to best adapt themselves to digital changes –and, relatedly, to adapt their business model according to an evolutionary dynamic'

responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 2: 'Software developers can achieve global sales at lower costs than conventional software distribution methods by registering their own software in their marketplaces without a need to build separate applications and distribution services.' | Page 1: 'Service can be used efficiently as the processes of the existing application are reduced. Various payment methods such as usage-based system based on cloud service characteristics can be employed. The cloud marketplace guarantees rapid cloud service construction and operation' | Page 9: 'The advantage is that the physical limitations of business selling software can be minimized, and the online implementation of sales channels can simplify customer secure methods.'

responses_by_article.article_title: Software as a service: Lessons from the video game industry
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Lower production costs compared to creating new games
Ability to launch games and improve them later based on feedback
Less expensive upfront investment in communication and marketing
Creation of steady revenue streams through updates and microtransactions
Easier to listen to community feedback and adapt accordingly
Ability to keep games alive for years with ongoing updates
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 8: 'It is clearly a useful model for developers, as they can launch an unfinished game and, if it is well received, improve on it later using updates and DLCs. They do not need to make a large upfront investment in communication and marketing to make a game a success. Once the game is launched, the CRM systems that form part of the GaaS approach make it easier to listen to the community for feedback, and adapt updates accordingly' | 'Financially, it is less expensive to create updates than a new game. The GaaS model not only improves the game by bringing in new ideas from the users, but it also lowers production costs, since it is concerned only with updates to an already functioning game. Additionally, the regular deployment of patches and updates can create a steady revenue stream for developers and publishers'

responses_by_article.article_title: Making a Business Out of (Predictive Application Management in) the Fog
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Save effort and costs involved in designing and implementing predictive features (Asset Manufacturers)
Bring new customers attracted by guarantees from predictive management (Asset Manufacturers)
Generate additional profits by selling predictive functionalities as add-on service (Asset Manufacturers)
Improve QoS (uptime, availability) of application management (Infrastructure Providers)
Achieve savings in operational costs and power consumption (Infrastructure Providers)
Define new suitable Service Level Objectives for SLAs in Fog landscapes (Infrastructure Providers)
Ease federation with other providers using same external solution (Infrastructure Providers)
Improve deployment QoS at reduced costs (Application Operators)
Achieve automated management of applications (Application Operators)
Obtain larger amount of predictable performance indicators (Application Operators)
Assess beforehand management choices and determine trade-offs among metrics (Application Operators)
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 6: 'They are expected to consider extending their management platforms with predictive, QoS-aware management capabilities, and they might consider it beneficial to save the effort and the costs involved in designing and implementing those new features' | 'Indeed, this can bring new customers (attracted by the guarantees derived from predictive management) to them and additional profits (if they decide to sell predictive functionalities as an add-on service to their customers)' | Page 3: 'Not only the adoption of predictive models that enable assessing their internal application management would lead to improved QoS (e.g., uptime, availability) but also to savings in terms of operational costs (e.g., power consumption). Last, but not least, the adoption of such techniques would lead to the definition of new and suitable Service Level Objectives (SLOs) for their Service Level Agreements (SLAs) in Fog landscapes' | Page 4: 'they could also see outsourcing the predictive services as a source of time and money savings, actually easing federation with other providers that rely on the same external solution' | Page 4: 'Finally, Application Operators will be attracted by the possibility of improving deployment QoS at reduced costs. They will be likely to pay for achieving automated management of their applications and a larger amount of predictable performance indicators' | Page 3: 'in addition to the possibility of assessing beforehand their management choices and improving them by a priori determining trade-offs among inversely correlated metrics (e.g., cost vs. QoS-assurance, security vs. response time)'

responses_by_article.article_title: Understanding the influence of absorptive capacity and ambidexterity on the process of business model change – the case of on-premise and cloud-computing software
responses_by_article.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Focus on core competencies by being relieved of burden of financing, managing and maintaining own IT infrastructures
Shift capital expenditures to operational expenditures
Increase strategic flexibility with lower sunk costs
Easy scalability of resources up or down in response to short contract periods
Readily available solutions reducing vendor lock-in and minimizing capital expenditures
Responding to competitive pressure and emerging customer demand
Emergence of disruptive innovation forcing business model adaptation
responses_by_article.source_citation: Page 3: 'Using SaaS enables companies to focus on core competencies, because they are relieved of the burden of financing, managing and maintaining their own IT infrastructures. Because services are provided on a pay-per-use basis, SaaS allows for the shifting of capital expenditures to operational expenditures. Furthermore, strategic flexibility increases, as sunk costs are lower and resources can easily be scaled up or down in response to short contract periods. Hence, the key drivers for adopting SaaS solutions are that they are readily available, reduce vendor lock-in and minimise capital expenditures' | Page 2: 'Owing to the increasing popularity of SaaS, incumbent ERP vendors have needed to adapt their long-established business models'
